ygData.subject: Re: Hard problems for HyperNEAT
ygData.msgSnippet: Jan, I think that s a difficult question because most interesting or challenging problems probably do not run to solution in 45 minutes.  One problem is that

Jan, I think that's a difficult question because most interesting or chal=
lenging problems probably do not run to solution in 45 minutes.  One proble=
m is that many interesting domains involve a domain-simulation (such as sim=
ulating physics), which makes evaluation take a long time.  So those types =
of domains (like quadruped walking) are likely ruled out.  Strategic domain=
s like board games are cheaper, but their expense comes from the opponent c=
omputing its move.  Perhaps if you create your own very rough checkers heur=
istic, or limit the ply-depth to which it can search, you could get a fast =
checkers player.  However, it is possible the problem could then become too=
 easy.  Parallel computing can be a help, but that depends on the computing=
 resources you have available.  It is possible that you will need to create=
 your own benchmark (perhaps some kind of image processing problem like the=
 boxes domain but a bit harder) to meet your needs.  Or, you might need to =
take an existing problem and modify it to be easier.  

Another problem is =
that there are other domains available (e.g. Keepaway soccer) but they are =
not in the same version of HyperNEAT so you can't use them directly with Hy=
perNEAT C++ 2.6.

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Jan van der Lugt <janlu=
gt@...> wrote:
>
> Hello everyone,
> 
> We are working on tuning the 30-som=
ething parameters for HyperNEAT (2.6 in
> our case) and we are looking for =
hard problems that do not take too much
> computational effort, which means=
 a run can take about 15 minutes. We
> already tried most of the problems s=
upplied with HyperNEAT, but most of them
> proved to be either too simple (=
near-optimal fitness within a few
> generations) or too expensive to run (o=
ne run can take hours). In this
> context a run is a complete run of HyperN=
EAT with n generations, not the
> evaluation of 1 generation. We cut back o=
n the number of generations
> (default is 300), so problems that take 30-45=
 minutes for a whole run are
> also ok.
> 
> Our interest lies only in usin=
g our tool to tune the parameters, so we won't
> use the source code of the=
 experiments for anything other than parameter
> tuning and we will hand ou=
r results (e.g. parameters and best performance)
> back to you in exchange =
for letting us use your work (provided we got to
> tuning your problem). As=
 a result of this work, we hope to be able to
> release validated tuning so=
ftware for use with HyperNEAT.
> 
> Regards,
> Jan van der Lugt
>
